wackpackr.util

Class LZWNode

  • java.lang.Object
    • wackpackr.util.LZWNode

  • public class LZWNode
extends Object
    Node in a trie-like structure used in LZW encoding.

    A node represents a dictionary entry: an index, and a unique byte sequence associated to that index. Each node stores the index number as-is, and the last byte value in the corresponding sequence.

    As each node stores only one byte, the sequences are built by walking down the trie, starting from the root and concatenating bytes encountered along the way. In other words, each node stores a certain byte sequence by virtue of its position in the trie: and, by extension, that sequence is a prefix to longer sequences stored by consequent nodes down the trie.

    Nodes have two kinds of pointers: child pointers that lead further down the trie; and lateral pointers that chain nodes of the same depth, much like a linked list. The child pointers (left and right) lead to nodes with the exact same prefix as the current node, but a different byte value at the last position; the lateral pointer (next), in turn, leads to the "first" node that takes as its prefix the byte sequence represented by the current node. The idea is that the child pointers are followed until the byte value to append next is found; and then the lateral pointer is followed to move on to the next position in the sequence.

    For example: to check if sequence [ 1, 2, 3, 4 ] exists in the trie, starting from the root, first follow the left and right pointers, until reaching a node with value 1; then from there follow the next pointer to a parallel node and, again, follow the left and right pointers, until reaching a node with value 2; and so on.

    The child pointers are arranged as a non-balanced binary trie. So, at worst, checking for the existence of a byte value in a certain position requires checking 256 nodes. However, in practice byte values are added to the (sub)trie randomly, which often results in a surprisingly balanced structure. Hence, typically no more than ~8 nodes need to be checked.

    The lateral pointers simply chain nodes in a linear fashion, so tracing a long sequence can be very time-consuming. However, there's a trick when operating the dictionary that avoids ever having to look further than one next pointer, so optimising would make no difference.

    Author:
    Juho Juurinen

      Constructor and Description
      LZWNode(int index, byte value)
      Constructs a new node in an LZW trie, representing a dictionary entry with the given index, and a byte sequence whose last byte is the given value.

      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      LZWNode get(byte... bytes)
      Searches for a node whose byte sequence is the byte sequence associated with this node plus the given bytes appended to the end; returns that node if it exists, or null otherwise.

      Returns the dictionary index stored in this node.
      boolean insert(LZWNode node, byte... bytes)
      Inserts the given node to the trie, such that the new node represents the byte sequence that equals to the sequence represented by this node appended with the given bytes.

    • Method Detail

      • get

        public LZWNode get(byte... bytes)
        Searches for a node whose byte sequence is the byte sequence associated with this node plus the given bytes appended to the end; returns that node if it exists, or null otherwise.
        Parameters:
        bytes - bytes to append to the sequence represented by this node
        Returns:
        sought-after node, if it exists

      • insert

        public boolean insert(LZWNode node,
                      byte... bytes)
        Inserts the given node to the trie, such that the new node represents the byte sequence that equals to the sequence represented by this node appended with the given bytes.

        Returns true if insertion was successful. Insertion fails if any of the prefixes of the given sequence do not exist, or if the given sequence already exists in the trie.

        Parameters:
        node - node to insert
        bytes - bytes to append to the sequence represented by this node
        Returns:
        true if insertion is successful; more specifically, if the byte sequence to insert does not yet exist in the trie, but all its prefixes do

      • index

        public int index()
        Returns the dictionary index stored in this node.
        Returns:
        dictionary index of this node
